Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis, Characterization and Chemistry of Model Gamma Alumina Heterogeneous Catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration: The NSF Chemical Catalysis Program supports the efforts of Professor Judith C. Yang to correlate experimental studies with first principles theoretical simulations in developing a fundamental understanding of the structure/chemical property relationship of a prototypical system based on platinum/gamma-alumina (Pt/gamma-Al2O3). Pt/gamma-Al2O3 is an important heterogeneous catalysts system used in oil refining, catalytic converters, and fuel cells. While much is known about the system, a significant gap exists between experiment and theory because commercially-available gamma-alumina is polycrystalline with ill-defined morphologies, crystallography and impurities. To bridge the gap, Yang's research group optimizes the oxidation conditions of single crystal nickel aluminum to produce reasonably flat, defect-free, single crystal gamma-Al2O3 films that are tens of nanometers thick (bulk-like). The characterization of size, morphologies, facets, dispersion and interfaces as well as electronic and chemical states under gas environments is accomplished by using the cutting-edge facilities at the Center for Functional Nanomaterials at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Direct comparison of the experimental data with theoretical modeling is accomplished through collaboration with Drs. Linlin Wang and Duane Johnson (Ames Laboratory and Iowa State University). This research project exposes graduate students to cutting edge research environments through combined university and national laboratory learning opportunities and collaborations. Undergraduates are also mentored in a team environment. Finally, Professor Yang serves and engages the local community via collaborations with the Pennsylvania Junior Academy of Science and the Materials Research Society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Catalysis is an important part of chemical manufacturing, with over 85% of all industrially produced chemicals relying on catalysts. Many useful catalysts are made from expensive materials such as noble metals and are therefore used in small amounts dispersed on high surface-area supports. Much research has shown that the choice of support material and the interaction between the catalyst and the support have a significant impact on the effectiveness and behavior of the catalyst, but these phenomena are not well understood fundamentally. Through in situ and high-resolution microscopy and spectroscopy, we are now able to study the structure of the supported catalyst with atomic detail to gain better understanding of the behavior of supported catalysts.

Intellectual merit: This project employed high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), X-ray and electron diffraction, aberration-corrected scanning TEM (STEM) and electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) combined with DFT and EELS simulations to study the structure of Pt supported on gamma-alumina (γ-Al2O3). Pt/γ-Al2O3 is a widely used industrial catalyst with applications in petroleum reforming and catalytic converters, making it an ideal model system. Model Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalysts consisting of single-crystal γ-Al2O3 supports and well-defined Pt nanoparticles were used for these studies. The model catalysts were prepared using e-beam evaporation, focused ion beam (FIB), and inverse-micelle nanoparticle synthesis techniques. We were able to analyze the various proposed structures of γ-Al2O3 using our model γ-Al2O3 and determine which model is most accurate, as the structure of γ-Al2O3 has been debated for many years and is still not clearly defined. We also studied the structure of the interface between Pt and γ-Al2O3, thereby determining a motif for the chemical bonding at that interface.

Broader impact: This project has been highly collaborative, establishing networks between researchers at the parent institution (University of Pittsburgh), and groups at University of Washington and the Fritz-Haber Institute in Germany. The project has contributed to the training of an underrepresented minority graduate student, as well as a post-doc and an undergraduate student. The graduate student, currently a PhD candidate, has attained significant mastery of cutting-edge modeling and characterization techniques that will prepare him to be a leader in this field. The undergraduate student has been trained in materials characterization techniques that have prepared him to undertake a scientific career either through graduate school or in industry. This project has helped introduce electron microscopy to high school students through the Pittsburgh Junior Academy of Science. The findings from this project have been disseminated through journals, conference presentations and proceedings.
